thread.title: Raley's gets new president, as CEO Teel to spend more time promoting healthy food
thread.title_full: Raley's gets new president, as CEO Teel to spend more time promoting healthy food

author: Sonya Sorich
title: Raley's gets new president, as CEO Teel to spend more time promoting healthy food
text: Raley's gets new president, as CEO Teel to spend more time promoting healthy food Feb 23, 2017, 2:32pm PST Industries & Tags Sonya Sorich Digital Editor Sacramento Business Journal Share Sonya Sorich Digital Editor Sacramento Business Journal Related Content Keith Knopf Ivie and Associates Keith Knopf , chief operating officer of Raley's , is now also taking on the title of president of the West Sacramento-based grocer, reflecting a change in focus by CEO and owner Michael Teel . Teel, who previously held the title of president, will remain as owner and CEO of the company, but he will spend more time in the community promoting healthy food choices, Raley's said in a news release Thursday. Keith Knopf Ivie and Associates Teel said in a prepared statement that he expects to focus "more on where we are going in the future and how we can realize our vision and purpose." "I am committed to continuing to build on our strong culture, and to support the passion our people have to infuse life with health and happiness by changing the way our customers eat, one plate at a time," he added. Knopf joined the company in 2015, shortly after Teel, the grandson of the grocer's founder, acquired majority ownership of Raley's. The company owns and operates 121 stores under four brands: Raley's, Bel Air Markets, Nob Hill Foods and Food Source. It also has 13 Aisle 1 Fuel Stations. Raley's is the Sacramento area's fourth-largest private company , with $3.1 billion in annual revenue, and the region's fifth-largest private-sector employer , with about 5,600 workers. Also on Thursday, Raley's announced that Mark Foley , senior vice president of human resources and labor relations has been promoted to chief people officer. Sonya Sorich is digital editor at the Sacramento Business Journal. She also oversees social media activity and writes about retailing, small business and restaurants. Related Content
